Center of Excellence in Immunology and Immunemediated Diseases

head.citation-title: Impact of notch1 deletion in macrophages on proinflammatory cytokine production and the outcome of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis
head.abstracts: Copyright © 2015 by The American Association of Immunologists, Inc. All rights reserved.Notch signaling is involved in regulating TLR-mediated responses in activated macrophages. In this study, we investigated the impact of Notch signaling in macrophages in an experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) model. To examine the impact of deficiency in Notch signaling in activated macrophages in EAE, an adoptive transfer of activated macrophages derived from Notch1fl/fl 3 Mx1cre+/2 (Notch1 knockout [N1KO]) or CSL/Rbp-jkfl/fl 3 Mx1cre+/2 (CSL/RBP-Jk KO) mice was performed prior to induction of EAE. Mice receiving activated N1KO macrophages showed decreased severity of EAE compared with mice receiving wild-type or CSL/RBP-Jk KO macrophages. In vitro restimulation of splenocytes by myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein 35-55 peptide from these mice revealed that cells from mice receiving N1KO macrophages produced significantly less IL-17 compared with the control mice, whereas IFN-g production was similar in both groups. We found that activated N1KO, but not CSL/RBP-Jk KO, macrophages produced less IL-6 and had lower CD80 expression compared with wild-type and did not exhibit any defect in IL-12p40/70 production, whereas activated macrophages from CSL/RBP-Jk KO mice phenocopied g-secretase inhibitor treatment for reduced IL-12p40/70 production. Furthermore, the nuclear translocation of the NF-κB subunit c-Rel was compromised in g-secretase inhibitor-treated and CSL/RBP-Jk KO but not N1KO macrophages. These results suggest that Notch1 and CSL/RBP-Jk in macrophages may affect the severity of EAE differently, possibly through modulating IL-6 and CD80 expression, which is involved in the Th17 but not Th1 response.

coredata.dc:description: Notch signaling is involved in regulating TLR-mediated responses in activated macrophages. In this study, we investigated the impact of Notch signaling in macrophages in an experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) model. To examine the impact of deficiency in Notch signaling in activated macrophages in EAE, an adoptive transfer of activated macrophages derived from Notch1fl/fl 3 Mx1cre+/2 (Notch1 knockout [N1KO]) or CSL/Rbp-jkfl/fl 3 Mx1cre+/2 (CSL/RBP-Jk KO) mice was performed prior to induction of EAE. Mice receiving activated N1KO macrophages showed decreased severity of EAE compared with mice receiving wild-type or CSL/RBP-Jk KO macrophages. Furthermore, the nuclear translocation of the NF-κB subunit c-Rel was compromised in g-secretase inhibitor-treated and CSL/RBP-Jk KO but not N1KO macrophages. These results suggest that Notch1 and CSL/RBP-Jk in macrophages may affect the severity of EAE differently, possibly through modulating IL-6 and CD80 expression, which is involved in the Th17 but not Th1 response.
